thread.title: John Lewis and Waitrose staff see annual bonus drop for the fifth year in a row

author: Tom Pegden
title: John Lewis and Waitrose staff see annual bonus drop for the fifth year in a row
text:
John Lewis and Waitrose staff see annual bonus drop for the fifth year in a row They'll get a 5 per cent bonus on top of their average pay Share You'll have to wait to shop the sale in store (Image: Getty) Share Get Business   Thank you for subscribing!   
Staff at John Lewis and Waitrose stores have seen their annual bonus drop for the fifth year in a row. 
“Partners” at the Leicester department store and Waitrose grocery stores around the county heard today that they would pick up a 5 per cent bonus on top of their average pay. 
That was down from 6 per cent last year and was the lowest since the landmark Highcross store opened. 
Two years ago staff picked up a 10 per cent bonus, and today’s extra pay was way off the 18 per cent bonus they received in 2011. 
The 2009 bonus, which was the first given out after the Highcross store opened in 2008, was 13 per cent. 
The drop is a reflection of the problems facing retail in the face of slowing and more cautious consumer spending and higher costs brought on by the fall in the value of sterling following the 2016 Brexit vote . 
Total pre-tax profits were down almost 22 per cent on last year at £289.2 million despite overall sales rising 2 per cent to almost £11.6 billion. 
Redundancy payments cost the group £72.8 million last year, with 1,440 partners leaving the business through cost-cutting. 
John Lewis Partnership chairman Sir Charlie Mayfield said: “As we anticipated, 2017 was a challenging year. 
“Consumer demand was subdued and we made significant changes to operations across the partnership which affected many partners. 
“However, their hard work throughout the year was key to delivering gross sales of £11.60 billion, up 2.0 per cent, with like-for-like increases [not including growth from new stores] in both Waitrose and John Lewis . 
“However, profit before partnership bonus, tax and exceptional items was down 21.9 per cent, mainly as a result of intensifying margin pressure in Waitrose . 
“We said in January 2017 that we were preparing for tougher trading conditions with weakness in sterling feeding through into cost prices, putting pressure on margin, and much higher exceptional costs as a result of an acceleration of planned changes. 
“This was why we chose to reduce the proportion of profits paid as partnership bonus last year so as to absorb these impacts while continuing to invest in the future and in strengthening our balance sheet. 
“We did both and I am pleased to say that despite lower profits, strong cash flow has enabled us to reduce our total net debts. 
“Partnership bonus has been awarded at 5 per cent. 
“We also remain committed to increasing pay rates for non-management partners, and in October we increased pay outside the annual pay review cycle for 17,000 partners. 
“As at January 2018, the average hourly rate of pay for a non-management partner was £8.91.” 
The business expects trading to stay “volatile” in the year ahead, with “continuing economic uncertainty and no let up in competitive intensity”. Read More
